summary:
Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction in real-world activities. BCI systems annotate the sensed signals in order to classify the analysis of brain states and dynamics in diverse daily-life circumstances. There is no complete and standardized formal semantic structure to model the BCI metadata annotations, which are essential to capture the descriptive and predictive features of the brain signals.

We present the BCI Ontology (BCI-O): the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real or virtual environments. At its core, BCI-O defines a human-environment interaction model for any BCI, based on design patterns and primarily aligned to the SOSA/SSN, SAN-IoT-O, and DUL ontologies. Its axiomatizations aid BCI systems to implement an ontological overlay upon vast data recording collections to support semantic query constructions to perform Adaptive BCI and reasoning for situation-specific data analytics to apply inference rules for Transfer Learning in multimodal classification.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are electronic systems that are used to determine a user’s brain states by collecting and analyzing her neuro-physiological signals including electroencephalogram (EEG), electrocardiogram (ECG), electrooculogram (EOG) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair or fight against her drowsiness. Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) techniques are commonly used to analyze those biological signals, which are highly situation and individual dependent, and non-stationary in characteristics, in order to classify her brain states. Lack of training data from individual users and comparable features among different users often hamper the accuracy and usefulness of BCI systems in real-world applications.

In a project in the research area of Advanced Computational Approaches under the Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA) program sponsored by the U.S. Army Research Laboratory (ARL), the Pervasive Embedding Technologies (PET) Lab in the National Chiao-Tung University (NCTU) in Taiwan has the chance to work with the Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience (SCCN) in the University of California in San Diego (UCSD) to develop a semantic model that can aid the search for correlated neuro-physiological features for characterizing an individual’s cognitive states including fatigue, vigilance and enlightenment and the gathering of useful data sets for conducting interpersonal Transfer Learning. This BCI Ontology was a product of that research project.

The project took a bottom-up approach; the SCCN team developed two sets of metadata vocabulary: the EEG Study Schema (ESS) and the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED) to describe the settings of the neuro-physiological recording and the specification of the neuro-physiological events respectively. Collectively, they were referred to as the BCI metadata. As the teams began to expand these metadata to cover more BCI experiments, the need to develop an ontological structure became obvious not only to accommodate future expansion of the vocabulary but also to specify the semantic relations among these concepts. Most notably, the syntax of HED 2 started to resemble the RDF format. Subsequent development of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), the semantic data repository and the federated SPARQL search all took place in NCTU with the results fed back to UCSD and ARL.

In order to employ BCI-O to accomplish the two goals mentioned above, the neuro-physiological signals/data sets collected from the experiments need to be processed for feature extraction and preliminary classification using existing ML algorithms. In the task of gathering data sets for Transfer Learning, inference rules shall be in place to specify the criteria of selecting data sets classified by existing algorithms for the learning process. In the task of deducing the correlated interpersonal features, the relations among the extracted features from different individuals shall be discovered through semantic search. Since BCI is a type of sensor-actuator system, it is only proper to align BCI-O with the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) frameworks. Because many BCI devices are connected to the Internet, BCI-O should also be aligned with the ontology for the Internet-of-Things (IoT-O).

An important contribution we made was the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations into BCI-O. The characteristics of biological and neurophysiological signals are known to be highly situation or context dependent. User’s physical conditions, time of day, environmental conditions can also affect the signals. In order to include these factors in the search for the correlated interpersonal features and the relevant data sets for Transfer Learning, we incorporated the core concepts of the UNITY world model for game development into BCI-O. We followed the human-environment interaction model in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) to integrate the concepts of context with those of sense and actuation.

In the rest of this paper, the BCI metadata for context, multi-modal data, and event annotations were first depicted. The structure, design principle, engineering and applications were then explained in subsequent sections. Lastly, the main contribution and future work were summarized in the conclusion.

The Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) Ontology (BCI-O) defines a conceptual framework for real-world BCI systems. It consists of two domains: the BCI domain, which includes observations, actuation, and interactions; and the context domain, based on gaming architectural modeling from Unity. The ontology is designed to capture multimodal data, annotate it with descriptive and predictive parameters, and provide machine-readable semantic models for software agents' interoperability.

BCI-O concepts are grouped into modules representing functional aspects of brain-computer interaction. Key topics include Subject (human engaging in activity), Context (environmental description with scenes and entities), Session (interaction between subject and context), Sense Model (contextual input data and events to the subject), Actuation Model (subject interacting with context), Annotation Tag (event markers based on context stimuli), Descriptor (external resource set extending entity descriptions). EEG concepts include subtypes for channel, device, modality, and record. The specification leaves open handling semantic expressiveness level.

The Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontology framework was extended for Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) domain, with SOSA/SSN providing conceptual templates and structures. The BCI-O's Sense Model leverages SSN to improve semantic interoperability and integration of BCI systems. The Actuation Model is based on the AAE ODP, integrating axiomatization models from W3C/OGC and IoT communities. The Context Model was built using Unity's gaming high-level modeling architecture, with core concepts aligned to DUL.

The BCI-ontology (BCI-O) was developed as part of a pervasive online brain-computer interface system. It's a proto-ontology that generalizes and expands on project specifications through modeling processes. The ontology considers two fundamental aspects: BCI interaction model complexity, which is addressed by identifying major players and flows based on HCI notions; and physical/virtual environments (contexts), which are abstracted from high-level concepts in the literature. The BCI-O was developed using a hybrid modeling style, including verbal/semi-structured vocabularies, logic-based upper ontologies, and structural-object frameworks.

The BCI-O proto-ontology was developed to enable semantic searching of big data sets for high-level processing via BCI metadata definitions. It has been successfully applied to heterogeneous BCI datasets from various applications, including stress neuroimaging and car driving tests. The ontology also aids in transfer learning operations by allowing the selection of relevant data segments based on categorized observations.

BCI-O models subject-context interactions while focusing on monitoring the brain dynamics. In the long term, we would like to take BCI-O as the basis towards generalizing a semantic model to describe how any human body bio-signal, not only from the brain, can be monitored and made to interact with computing interfaces. Initially, this work would lead to BCI-O's generalization towards a Bio-signal Computer-Interaction Ontology. This modeling task is planned to be one of the main development drivers in the future for a set of ontological frameworks to capture the different bio-signal markers and technological interfaces for the entire human body: organs such as the brain, heart, liver, and systems including nervous, integumentary, and endocrine.

Additionally, there is an ongoing effort on proposing some extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation. We are following closely the new proposed concepts and relationships and providing our feedback from the BCI-O perspective in their ongoing discussions, with special interest for issue #1028 regarding the Homogeneity of an Observation Collection. BCI-O will be updated accordingly following the structure and alignments of these extensions after the proposal becomes stable. Lastly, some BCI applications keep part of their metadata stored in standard relational database systems. As an aside project, we are planning to work on an OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O, so that those relevant metadata sets can be queried through a restrictive version of BCI-O.

As a foundational model for real-world BCI, BCI-O will become an important tool to aid large-scale BCI data analytics models and processes, due primarily to its OWL 2 formal structure. Semantic reasoning based tasks of BCI-O's axiomatizations enable BCI systems to carry out two major jobs: first, to apply inference rules to aid machine learning techniques, such as feature-based transfer learning in online multimodal EEG classification, and second, to perform Adaptive BCI, which involves training and refining brain state prediction and classification models based on relevant data sets constructed through semantic data queries.

Another key contribution of BCI-O is its novel Context Model. This model associates the context architectonic definition with the data recordings, making BCI systems semantically context-aware for real and virtual-world situations. Thus, it provides a semantic foundation for augmented BCI, assisting ambient intelligence settings in sensor systems for any kind of BCI. As a domain ontology for BCI sensors and actuators, BCI-O allows for semantically informed BCI analytics of sensor and actuator data patterns, including unambiguous searchability, similarities, simulations, and predictions, as well as semantic interoperability based on its alignments. This enables easy integration, reusability, and extensibility into the Linked Data world for all kinds of BCI. In general, its axiomatizations enable BCI systems to apply Semantic Web technologies for data analysis, serving as a form of semantic middleware for BCI sensor and actuator networks.

Predicate-will_largely_enable.label: will largely enable
Predicate-will_largely_enable.description: The predicate 'will largely enable' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the actions or developments described by the subject will have a significant impact on making possible or facilitating the occurrence of the event or phenomenon represented by the object. In this sense, the subject is seen as a catalyst for the object's emergence or advancement.

Predicate-will_enable.label: will enable
Predicate-will_enable.description: The predicate 'will enable' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the presence or activation of the subject will facilitate or make possible the occurrence or achievement of the object. In this sense, it implies a potential for the subject to unlock or unleash the capabilities or effects described by the object.

Predicate-involves.label: involves
Predicate-involves.description: The predicate 'involves' indicates a relationship where the subject (real-world activities or any other entity) has an inherent connection with, participates in, or encompasses the object (mainstream human-computer interaction or another concept). This connection can be one of inclusion, participation, membership, or association. The predicate suggests that there is some level of involvement, engagement, or entanglement between the subject and the object.

Predicate-annotate.label: annotate
Predicate-annotate.description: To add or attach a label, note, comment, or interpretation to something, typically in order to clarify its meaning, significance, or context.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates that the subject refers to a concept or entity that currently exists or has relevance. It suggests an ongoing or contemporary significance, highlighting the subject's presence or prominence at this moment.

Predicate-formalizes.label: formalizes
Predicate-formalizes.description: Formalizes establishes a structured and standardized representation of information or concepts, connecting the subject (presenting entity) to the object (metadata), thereby making it more organized, accessible, and usable.

Predicate-integrates.label: integrates
Predicate-integrates.description: The predicate 'integrates' represents a relationship where the subject (a conceptual framework or system) brings together, unifies, or harmonizes different components, concepts, or models to form a cohesive whole. This integration can occur at various levels, such as combining theoretical frameworks with practical applications, merging distinct domains of knowledge, or reconciling seemingly disparate ideas into a coherent understanding.

Predicate-defines_a_human-environment_in.label: defines a human-environment interaction model for any BCI
Predicate-defines_a_human-environment_in.description: This predicate establishes a connection between a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) and a conceptual representation of how humans interact with their environment. It describes the process by which a BCI defines or outlines a framework for understanding human-environment interactions, encompassing various aspects such as perception, cognition, behavior, and feedback loops.

Predicate-based_on_design_patterns_and_p.label: based on design patterns and primarily aligned to the
Predicate-based_on_design_patterns_and_p.description: This predicate indicates that the subject's structure or organization is grounded in design patterns and primarily aligned with the concepts, principles, or standards represented by the object. The relationship suggests a connection between the subject's internal architecture and an external framework or ontology.

Predicate-based_on_design_patterns_and_p.label: based on design patterns and primarily aligned to the SOSA/SSN, SAN-IoT-O, and DUL ontologies
Predicate-based_on_design_patterns_and_p.description: This predicate indicates that the subject's definition or description is grounded in design patterns and primarily adheres to a set of standardized ontological frameworks (SOSA/SSN, SAN-IoT-O, and DUL). The object represents one or more of these ontologies, which serve as the foundation for understanding the subject's concept or model.

Predicate-implement_an_ontological_overl.label: implement an ontological overlay upon
Predicate-implement_an_ontological_overl.description: To apply a conceptual framework or structure (ontological overlay) to organize and relate concepts, entities, or relationships within a given domain or dataset. This predicate connects the subject with an existing body of knowledge or data by imposing a coherent and meaningful organization upon it.

Predicate-support.label: support
Predicate-support.description: To provide or maintain a foundation for something to exist, operate, or be effective. The predicate 'support' indicates that the subject enables, facilitates, or sustains the object's purpose, functionality, or relevance.

Predicate-apply.label: apply
Predicate-apply.description: The predicate 'apply' indicates a relationship where the subject takes an action or uses a rule to transform, utilize, or operate on the object. This can involve applying logical rules, algorithms, or techniques to achieve a specific outcome or solve a problem.

Predicate-are_used_to_determine_a_users.label: are used to determine a user's
Predicate-are_used_to_determine_a_users.description: This predicate indicates that something (the subject) serves as a means or method for identifying or understanding an aspect of human behavior or cognition related to a specific individual (the object).

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a relationship of equivalence or classification between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (Brain-Computer Interaction  BCIs) belongs to, comprises, or can be categorized as one type of electronic systems.

Predicate-are_used_to_analyze.label: are used to analyze
Predicate-are_used_to_analyze.description: The predicate 'are used to analyze' indicates a relationship between the subject (a set of methods or approaches) and an object (data or information), where the subject's purpose or function is to examine, interpret, or understand the characteristics or patterns within the object.

Predicate-classify.label: classify
Predicate-classify.description: To categorize or group something into a specific category or class based on its characteristics, features, or properties.

Predicate-are_commonly_used_to_analyze.label: are commonly used to analyze
Predicate-are_commonly_used_to_analyze.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between the subject (a method or technique) and an object (data or information). The subject is commonly employed to extract insights, identify patterns, or draw conclusions from the object. In general, this predicate suggests that the subject plays a crucial role in understanding or interpreting the object.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: To provide means to offer or make available something (e.g. resources, information, support) that can be used by the subject for a specific purpose or goal.

Predicate-are_used_to_determine_a_users_.label: are used to determine a user's brain states by collecting and analyzing her neuro-physiological signals including electroencephalogram (EEG), electrocardiogram (ECG), electrooculogram (EOG) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair or fight against her drowsiness.
Predicate-are_used_to_determine_a_users_.description: The predicate connects a system (subject) with its purpose of determining and responding to an individual's brain states, by collecting and analyzing their neuro-physiological signals. This connection enables the system to actuate specific responses based on the user's brain activity.

Predicate-work_with.label: work with
Predicate-work_with.description: The predicate 'work with' indicates a collaborative relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (an organization or entity) engages in joint activities, shares resources, or coordinates efforts with the object (another organization or entity). This connection implies mutual cooperation, exchange of knowledge, skills, or expertise, and potentially leads to shared goals, outcomes, or benefits.

Predicate-has_the_chance_to_work_with.label: has the chance to work with
Predicate-has_the_chance_to_work_with.description: Indicates a potential opportunity or possibility of collaboration between two entities (subject and object), suggesting that they may engage in joint activities, share resources, or exchange knowledge.

Predicate-was_a_product_of.label: was a product of
Predicate-was_a_product_of.description: The predicate 'was a product of' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has its origin or development from the object. It implies a sense of derivation, creation, or emergence where the object played a significant role in shaping or producing the subject.

Predicate-developed.label: developed
Predicate-developed.description: The predicate 'developed' indicates a process or state where something (the subject) has been transformed into a more advanced, refined, or sophisticated form, often resulting in the creation of new knowledge, concepts, or structures. This transformation can involve various forms of intellectual, creative, or practical work.

Predicate-referred_to_as.label: referred to as
Predicate-referred_to_as.description: The predicate 'referred to as' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, Brain-Computer Interaction  BCIs) has an alternative or synonymous name, which is provided by the object (metadata). This connection represents a mapping between two names that can be used interchangeably.

Predicate-were_referred_to_as.label: were referred to as
Predicate-were_referred_to_as.description: The predicate 'were referred to as' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject has been given a name or label by which it can be identified, characterized, or distinguished. This connection implies that the subject's identity or essence is reflected in the object, which serves as a descriptive term or title.

Predicate-took_place.label: took place
Predicate-took_place.description: Indicates that an event or situation occurred at a specific time and location. The predicate 'took place' connects the subject (the entity undergoing change or development) to the object (a context, setting, or environment), suggesting that the subject's existence, evolution, or significance was defined by its occurrence within the specified circumstances.

Predicate-employ.label: employ
Predicate-employ.description: To employ means to utilize or make use of something (in this case, a resource such as an algorithm) for a specific purpose or function. This predicate indicates that the subject has chosen and integrated the object into its operations or processes.

Predicate-accomplish.label: accomplish
Predicate-accomplish.description: To accomplish a goal or objective means to successfully complete it, fulfill its requirements, and achieve the desired outcome. The subject of the predicate has taken action to bring about the realization of the object, which represents the target or end-state that was aimed for.

Predicate-of_selecting.label: of selecting
Predicate-of_selecting.description: The predicate 'of selecting' indicates a relationship between its subject and object, where the subject defines or specifies the criteria for choosing or identifying instances of the object. In general, it suggests that the subject plays a role in determining what constitutes an instance of the object.

Predicate-shall_specify_the_criteria_of_.label: shall specify the criteria of selecting data sets classified by existing algorithms for the learning process
Predicate-shall_specify_the_criteria_of_.description: This predicate indicates that a set of guidelines or standards will be established to determine which pre-classified datasets are suitable for use in a machine learning process. The criteria specified by this predicate serve as a filter, helping to ensure the quality and relevance of the data used for training models.

Predicate-deduces.label: deduces
Predicate-deduces.description: To deduce means to infer or conclude something from available information, often through logical reasoning and analysis. The predicate 'deduces' connects the subject (the entity performing the deduction) with the object (the conclusion or inference drawn), indicating a process of logical derivation that yields new knowledge or understanding.

Predicate-shall_be_discovered_through.label: shall be discovered through
Predicate-shall_be_discovered_through.description: Indicates that a relationship or pattern between two entities (subject and object) will be uncovered or revealed using a specific method or technique.

Predicate-align_with.label: align with
Predicate-align_with.description: To align with means to harmonize or coordinate two entities (subject and object), typically by sharing common principles, standards, or goals. This predicate indicates a relationship of mutual understanding, compatibility, or equivalence between the subject and object, suggesting that they operate within similar frameworks, share compatible semantics, or have complementary purposes.

Predicate-are_known_to_be.label: are known to be
Predicate-are_known_to_be.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject's properties, attributes, or features are recognized as being true or accurate within a specific situation, context, or scope. The predicate suggests that there exists some understanding, recognition, or acknowledgment of the subject's characteristics by someone or something.

Predicate-are_known_to_be_highly.label: are known to be highly
Predicate-are_known_to_be_highly.description: This predicate indicates a strong association between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has a high degree of some quality, attribute, or property described by the object. The phrase 'are known to be highly' implies a level of recognition or acknowledgment of this characteristic, making it more prominent or significant.

Predicate-depicted.label: depicted
Predicate-depicted.description: The predicate 'depicted' indicates a representation or portrayal of something (the subject) through another medium or form (the object). It suggests that the subject has been captured, conveyed, or expressed in some way by the object. In general, it implies a connection between the subject and the object where the subject is being represented or described.

Predicate-explained_in_subsequent_sectio.label: explained in subsequent sections
Predicate-explained_in_subsequent_sectio.description: This predicate indicates that the subject provides a comprehensive overview or introduction to a topic, with more detailed information and explanations presented later on. The object refers to the specific parts of text where these additional details are found.

Predicate-explained.label: explained
Predicate-explained.description: The predicate 'explained' indicates a relationship where the subject provides clarification or insight into the object. It suggests that the subject has shed light on the nature, purpose, or significance of the object, making it more comprehensible to others.

Predicate-were_summarized_in.label: were summarized in
Predicate-were_summarized_in.description: The predicate 'were summarized in' indicates a relationship where the subject (a summary or an abstracted form of information) was condensed and presented within the object (typically, a specific context, framework, or medium). This connection implies that the subject's essence or key points were distilled into a concise format for easier comprehension or communication.

Predicate-summarized.label: summarized
Predicate-summarized.description: The predicate 'summarized' indicates that the subject (in this case, a main contribution) has been condensed or abstracted into its essential elements to form the object (the conclusion). This connection implies that the subject's key points have been distilled and presented in a concise manner.

Predicate-perform.label: perform
Predicate-perform.description: To perform a predicate connects an agent (the subject) to an action or activity (the object), indicating that the agent engages with and carries out the activity, often resulting in some outcome or consequence.

Predicate-defines.label: defines
Predicate-defines.description: The predicate 'defines' establishes a relationship between its subject and object, indicating that the subject provides a clear and precise explanation or description of the object. In this sense, it specifies the meaning, scope, or boundaries of the object, often in terms of conceptual components, categories, or frameworks.

Predicate-is_a_part_of.label: is a part of
Predicate-is_a_part_of.description: The predicate 'is a part of' indicates that the subject and object are related as constituent parts or components. It suggests a hierarchical relationship where the subject is an integral component or aspect of the larger entity represented by the object.

Predicate-underlying.label: underlying
Predicate-underlying.description: Indicates that a subject concept or idea serves as the foundation, basis, or underlying structure for an object. This predicate suggests a relationship of support, grounding, or underpinning between the subject and object.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., Sense Model) relies on or derives its characteristics, properties, or structure from the object (e.g., Stimulus-Sensor-Observation Ontology Design Pattern). This connection suggests that the subject's definition, functionality, or meaning is grounded in or influenced by the object. In general, 'based on' implies a foundation, basis, or underlying principle for the subject.

Predicate-aligned_to.label: aligned to
Predicate-aligned_to.description: The predicate 'aligned to' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has its structure or organization conforming to, being consistent with, or following the principles and guidelines of another entity (the object). This alignment suggests that the subject is grounded in or informed by the concepts, terminology, or standards represented by the object.

Predicate-described.label: described
Predicate-described.description: The predicate 'described' indicates that a description or explanation of something (the object) has been provided for a particular subject. It connects the subject to the object by stating how the object relates to, explains, or characterizes the subject.

Predicate-aligned.label: aligned
Predicate-aligned.description: The predicate 'aligned' indicates a relationship where two or more entities (subject and object) share a common framework, structure, or set of principles that enables them to be related, compared, or integrated. This alignment can occur at various levels, such as conceptual, semantic, or formal, allowing for the establishment of connections between seemingly disparate domains.

Predicate-corresponds_to_the_same_concep.label: corresponds to the same concept as in HCI literature
Predicate-corresponds_to_the_same_concep.description: This predicate indicates that the subject and object share a common conceptual meaning or interpretation within the field of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI). It suggests an equivalence or alignment between the subject's concept and the one described in HCI literature, implying a shared understanding or framework.

Predicate-taken_from.label: taken from
Predicate-taken_from.description: The predicate 'taken from' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI)) has its foundation or basis in the object (domain concepts). It suggests that BCI draws inspiration, ideas, or principles from domain concepts to inform its development or understanding.

Predicate-are_taken_from.label: are taken from
Predicate-are_taken_from.description: The predicate 'are taken from' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, domain concepts) obtains or derives its meaning, definition, or characteristics from the object (semi-structured standard vocabularies and formats). This connection suggests that the subject's essence is rooted in or influenced by the object, which provides a foundation for understanding or describing the subject.

Predicate-stores.label: stores
Predicate-stores.description: The predicate 'stores' indicates a relationship where the subject (a container or repository) holds or maintains the object (data, information, or schemes), suggesting a sense of organization, management, and possibly even ownership.

Predicate-tailored_towards.label: tailored towards
Predicate-tailored_towards.description: The predicate 'tailored towards' indicates that the subject (e.g., XDF) has been designed or adapted to specifically work with or process the object (e.g., bio-signal data). This implies a close relationship between the two, suggesting that the subject is optimized for handling or analyzing the object in some way.

Predicate-describes_and_documents.label: describes and documents
Predicate-describes_and_documents.description: This predicate connects a hierarchical structure of metadata to a set of related data or research outputs by describing their organization, categorization, and documentation. It implies that the subject provides a framework for understanding the object's content, context, and relationships.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject possesses, contains, or is related to the object in some way.

Predicate-is_tailored_towards.label: is tailored towards
Predicate-is_tailored_towards.description: The predicate 'is tailored towards' indicates that the subject has been designed or structured to accommodate or be compatible with a specific type of information or entity, as represented by the object. This relationship suggests a purposeful alignment between the subject and the object, implying that the subject is optimized for processing, analyzing, or working with the object in some way.

Predicate-collecting_multimodal_data_fro.label: collecting multimodal data from a subject
Predicate-collecting_multimodal_data_fro.description: The predicate 'collecting multimodal data from a subject' describes an action of gathering and recording various forms of information (e.g., audio, video, physiological signals) that are related to or generated by a specific individual. This process involves capturing and storing the subject's responses, behaviors, or internal states in a way that preserves their multimodality.

Predicate-annotate_the_data_with_descrip.label: annotate the data with descriptive and predictive parameters
Predicate-annotate_the_data_with_descrip.description: To associate specific characteristics or properties (descriptive parameters) and/or future-oriented information (predictive parameters) to a dataset, providing context and insights about the data's structure, relationships, and potential outcomes.

Predicate-explain.label: explain
Predicate-explain.description: To clarify or make understandable the relationship between two concepts by providing a logical and coherent account of how they are connected.

Predicate-corresponds_to.label: corresponds to
Predicate-corresponds_to.description: The predicate 'corresponds to' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI)) has an equivalent or analogous meaning with respect to the object (context). This connection suggests that there exists a logical or semantic correspondence between the two entities, implying that they share similar characteristics, concepts, or principles.

Predicate-defining.label: defining
Predicate-defining.description: The predicate 'defining' indicates a relationship where the subject (ontology) establishes or specifies the meaning of the object (core, generic, and relevant consensual concepts), thereby providing a clear understanding or characterization of these concepts within its scope.

Predicate-developing.label: developing
Predicate-developing.description: The predicate 'developing' indicates that the subject is actively creating or refining something new, often with a focus on improvement, expansion, or refinement. It suggests a process of growth, evolution, or maturation from an initial state to a more advanced or sophisticated one.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates a state of being or equivalence between the subject and object, suggesting that they share a common identity, characteristic, or property.

Predicate-defines_the_conceptual_compone.label: defines the conceptual components in any BCI through a bidirectional subject-context interaction model: a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), as depicted in the relevant figure
Predicate-defines_the_conceptual_compone.description: This predicate establishes a connection between the subject (e.g., human beings interacting with an environment) and object (e.g., brain-computer interface - BCI), highlighting how the subject's interactions shape or are shaped by the conceptual components of any BCI. The bidirectional interaction model, comprising Sense Model (context to subject) and Actuation Model (subject to context), provides a framework for understanding the dynamic relationship between the subject and their environment.

Predicate-are_grouped_into.label: are grouped into
Predicate-are_grouped_into.description: The predicate 'are grouped into' indicates a categorization or classification of entities (subject), where they are organized and structured according to specific criteria or categories, resulting in distinct groups or modules (object).

Predicate-represents.label: represents
Predicate-represents.description: The predicate 'represents' indicates that the subject (in this case, several modules) serves as an embodiment or manifestation of the object (a key topic), conveying its essence, characteristics, or significance.

Predicate-is_in.label: is in
Predicate-is_in.description: The predicate 'is in' indicates a relationship of containment or membership between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has a specific role or position within the scope defined by the object, which can be physical, conceptual, or abstract.

Predicate-are_presented_with.label: are presented with
Predicate-are_presented_with.description: The predicate 'are presented with' indicates that the subject (in this case, modules) receives or has access to information about something else (the object), which provides a brief overview or summary of what they are. This connection implies a relationship where the subject's understanding is enhanced by having this additional context.

Predicate-is_equivalent_to.label: is equivalent to
Predicate-is_equivalent_to.description: The predicate 'is equivalent to' indicates a relationship between two entities where they share identical characteristics or properties. It suggests that the subject and object are interchangeable, having the same meaning, function, or representation in different contexts.

Predicate-captures.label: captures
Predicate-captures.description: To capture something means to represent it accurately and comprehensively, often through a process of abstraction, simplification, or analysis. In this sense, the predicate 'captures' indicates that the subject (Context) has successfully conveyed its essence, characteristics, or features into the object (architectural description), which serves as a representation or summary of those aspects.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' indicates that the subject's foundation or justification lies with the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject relies heavily on, draws inspiration from, or has its underlying principles rooted in the object.

Predicate-depicts.label: depicts
Predicate-depicts.description: The predicate 'depicts' represents a relationship where the subject conveys or illustrates its meaning through the object. In this sense, it connects the subject to the object by indicating that the subject's essence or characteristics are reflected in the object.

Predicate-enable.label: enable
Predicate-enable.description: To enable means to make something possible or feasible by providing necessary conditions, resources, or support. It implies a facilitative relationship between the subject (conceptual components) and object (complexity definitions), where the former provides the means for the latter to exist, operate, or be understood.

Predicate-depicts_how_the_subject_can_in.label: depicts how the subject can interact with
Predicate-depicts_how_the_subject_can_in.description: This predicate describes a conceptual relationship between the subject and object, indicating that the subject (e.g., an actuation model) provides insight into how it can be used or manipulated by interacting with something else (the context). The depiction reveals the possible ways in which the subject can engage with its environment, highlighting potential interactions, interfaces, or modes of operation.

Predicate-groups.label: groups
Predicate-groups.description: The predicate 'groups' indicates a categorization or classification of entities into distinct sets. It suggests that the subject has some inherent property or characteristic that allows it to group, organize, or aggregate multiple objects together.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' establishes a relationship between its subject and object by conveying information about or providing an explanation of the object's characteristics, properties, or essence. It implies that the subject has some level of understanding, interpretation, or representation of the object, which is then conveyed through this description.

Predicate-are_aligned_to.label: are aligned to
Predicate-are_aligned_to.description: The predicate 'are aligned to' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, an Observation) has its underlying principles or concepts connected with and consistent with those of the object (the axioms for modeling observations). This alignment suggests that there is a harmonious correspondence between the two entities, implying a shared framework or structure.

Predicate-are_specific_concepts_aligned_.label: are specific concepts aligned to
Predicate-are_specific_concepts_aligned_.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject's inherent or defined concepts are connected or mapped to the object. The connection can be one-to-one, many-to-many, or even hierarchical in nature. In general, this predicate suggests that there exists an alignment or correspondence between the abstract representations of the subject (i.e., specific concepts) and the object, which provides a framework for understanding, modeling, or interpreting the subject's properties or behaviors.

Predicate-are_related_to.label: are related to
Predicate-are_related_to.description: The predicate 'are related to' indicates a connection or association between the subject and object. It suggests that there exists some kind of link, similarity, or commonality between them, which can be based on various factors such as category, type, function, origin, or other relevant characteristics.

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' connects the subject to a list of additional attributes or characteristics that are inherent to it. It indicates a relationship where the subject possesses all the qualities or features specified by the object, which can be multiple and distinct.

Predicate-include.label: include
Predicate-include.description: The predicate 'include' indicates that the subject contains or comprises the object. It suggests a relationship of containment, membership, or integration between the two entities.

Predicate-include_(1).label: include
Predicate-include_(1).description: To include means to encompass or comprise something as a part of a larger whole. It indicates that the subject has a relationship with the object where the object is considered an integral component, aspect, or characteristic of the subject.

Predicate-depicts_how.label: depicts how
Predicate-depicts_how.description: The predicate 'depicts how' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., Actuation Model) represents or illustrates the manner or process by which something occurs, as described by the object (e.g., The subject).

Predicate-can_interact_with.label: can interact with
Predicate-can_interact_with.description: Indicates a relationship where the subject has the ability to engage or communicate with the object in some way. This predicate suggests that there exists an opportunity for mutual influence, exchange of information, or reciprocal action between the subject and the context.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, an Annotation Tag) encompasses or contains the object (event markers), suggesting that the tag has some relevance to or describes the event markers.

Predicate-includes_event_markers_based_o.label: includes event markers based on and response markers based on machine learning models for annotations on specific data segments.
Predicate-includes_event_markers_based_o.description: This predicate indicates that a subject (typically an annotation tag or label) includes event markers and response markers, which are generated based on machine learning models applied to specific data segments. The connection between the subject and object lies in the fact that the subject's characteristics or properties are derived from the analysis of these data segments using machine learning algorithms.

Predicate-define.label: define
Predicate-define.description: To specify or determine the meaning of something by establishing its boundaries and characteristics. The predicate 'define' connects the subject to a concept or entity that is being clarified, categorized, or described in terms of its essential features.

Predicate-extends.label: extends
Predicate-extends.description: The predicate 'extends' indicates a relationship where the subject conceptually builds upon or adds to the object. This can imply inheritance of properties, expansion of scope, or supplementation of existing information.

Predicate-represent.label: represent
Predicate-represent.description: To represent means to convey or symbolize a concept, idea, or category through a specific entity, phenomenon, or classification. The predicate 'represent' establishes an abstract relationship between the subject and object, indicating that the subject embodies, exemplifies, or instantiates the characteristics of the object.

Predicate-borrowed_from.label: borrowed from
Predicate-borrowed_from.description: The predicate 'borrowed from' indicates that the subject has acquired or taken inspiration from the object, often implying a sense of intellectual property rights or creative influence. This relationship suggests that the subject has drawn upon or incorporated elements from the object into their own work, concept, or idea.

Predicate-were_borrowed_from.label: were borrowed from
Predicate-were_borrowed_from.description: Indicates that a concept or idea was taken from another source as inspiration or foundation for its development. The predicate connects the subject (the thing being described) to an external resource, implying that the subject's characteristics, properties, or definitions were influenced by this source.

Predicate-can_express.label: can express
Predicate-can_express.description: The predicate 'can express' indicates that a subject has the ability to convey or represent an object through some means of communication. This connection implies that the subject possesses the capacity to translate, describe, or illustrate the characteristics, features, or concepts represented by the object.

Predicate-extending.label: extending
Predicate-extending.description: The predicate 'extending' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., interoperable models) expands or builds upon the object (e.g., BCI-O), potentially adding new features, capabilities, or scope to it. This connection suggests that the subject is contributing to the growth, development, or evolution of the object in some way.

Predicate-express.label: express
Predicate-express.description: To express means to convey or represent a concept, idea, or relationship between two entities. It implies a connection or mapping from one domain or representation to another, often involving abstraction and simplification of complex information.

Predicate-leaves_open.label: leaves open
Predicate-leaves_open.description: Leaves open refers to a situation where something (the subject) does not specify or determine the relationship between two entities, leaving room for interpretation or further elaboration. In this sense, it connects the subject and object by indicating that there is no clear or definitive connection established between them.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: Indicates that a subject exploits or leverages an object to achieve its purpose. The uses predicate represents a relationship of utilization, where the subject relies on the object's capabilities, properties, or functionality to operate effectively.

Predicate-leverages.label: leverages
Predicate-leverages.description: The predicate 'leverages' indicates a relationship where the subject (BCI-O) takes advantage of or utilizes the object (SSN), often to achieve some goal, gain an insight, or solve a problem. This connection implies that the subject relies on or exploits the properties or characteristics of the object.

Predicate-gives.label: gives
Predicate-gives.description: The predicate 'gives' indicates a transfer of possession or control from the subject to the object. It implies that the subject has authority over the object and intentionally conveys it to another entity, potentially changing its ownership, custody, or responsibility.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship of offering or making available something (the object) by someone or something (the subject). It suggests that the subject has access to, furnishes with, or supplies the object. This connection implies a sense of availability, provisionality, and possibly even responsibility for ensuring the existence or quality of the object.

Predicate-employs.label: employs
Predicate-employs.description: The predicate 'employs' indicates a relationship of utilization or deployment between two entities. It suggests that one entity (the subject) uses, utilizes, or makes use of another entity (the object), often for a specific purpose or function.

Predicate-helps_to_improve.label: helps to improve
Predicate-helps_to_improve.description: The predicate 'helps to improve' indicates a causal relationship between the subject (an entity or process) and the object (a concept, state, or condition), where the subject contributes to enhancing or advancing the object's quality, effectiveness, or understanding.

Predicate-helps_to_connect.label: helps to connect
Predicate-helps_to_connect.description: The predicate 'helps to connect' indicates a relationship where the subject facilitates or enables communication, integration, or association between two entities (the object), often by providing a common framework, standard, or infrastructure that allows them to interact, share information, or coordinate their activities.

Predicate-connect.label: connect
Predicate-connect.description: To establish a relationship or link between two entities, concepts, or systems, enabling communication, interaction, or integration. This predicate indicates that the subject and object are connected through some common thread, allowing for information exchange, coordination, or mutual influence.

Predicate-is_interested_in.label: is interested in

The relationship suggests a filtering or categorization process where specific attributes are used to restrict or define the scope of the object, which can be sessions, subjects, records, or any other relevant entities.

Predicate-is_comprised_of.label: is comprised of
Predicate-is_comprised_of.description: The predicate 'is comprised of' indicates that the subject is made up or composed of one or more distinct entities or components. It implies a relationship where the subject's essence, nature, or identity is derived from its constituent parts.

Predicate-with.label: with
Predicate-with.description: The predicate 'with' indicates a relationship of association or accompaniment between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has some connection to, relies on, or utilizes the object in order to achieve its purpose.

Predicate-is_used_for.label: is used for
Predicate-is_used_for.description: The predicate 'is used for' indicates a purpose or function that something (the subject) serves. It describes how the subject contributes to achieving a particular goal, process, or outcome (the object).

Predicate-used_to_ensure_that_big_data_s.label: used to ensure that big data sets were semantically searchable for high-level processing via
Predicate-used_to_ensure_that_big_data_s.description: The predicate 'used to ensure that big data sets were semantically searchable for high-level processing via' indicates a relationship where the subject (a conceptual framework, ontology, or metadata definition) was designed and utilized as a means of enabling efficient querying, analysis, and manipulation of large datasets by providing semantic search capabilities.

Predicate-focus_on.label: focus on
Predicate-focus_on.description: To focus on means to concentrate one's attention or effort on a particular aspect, process, or phenomenon. It implies prioritizing and directing mental resources towards understanding, analyzing, or manipulating the object of consideration.

Predicate-subject-context_interactions.label: subject-context interactions
Predicate-subject-context_interactions.description: The predicate 'subject-context interactions' describes a relationship where the subject (a system or entity) interacts with its context in some way. This interaction can involve influencing, being influenced by, or responding to the context, which may include internal or external factors that shape the behavior of the subject.

Predicate-can_be_monitored_and_made_to_i.label: can be monitored and made to interact with
Predicate-can_be_monitored_and_made_to_i.description: This predicate indicates a relationship where the subject (a physical or biological entity) has the potential for its internal state or processes to be tracked and influenced by an external system, typically represented by the object. The connection between the subject and object implies that there is some form of interface or gateway that enables monitoring and interaction.

Predicate-lead_to.label: lead to
Predicate-lead_to.description: The predicate 'lead to' indicates that the subject has a causal relationship with the object, implying that the subject's existence or occurrence contributes to or brings about the state of being described by the object. In general, it suggests a directional flow from the subject towards the object, where the subject is the initiating factor and the object represents the outcome or consequence.

Predicate-generalize_towards.label: generalize towards
Predicate-generalize_towards.description: To generalize towards means to direct or orient a concept, theory, or framework (subject) towards a specific domain, ontology, or area of study (object), often with the intention of applying or integrating it within that context. This predicate indicates an intentional movement or alignment between the subject and object, suggesting a connection or relationship that facilitates understanding, application, or extension.

Predicate-capture.label: capture
Predicate-capture.description: To capture refers to the process of identifying, recording, or grasping a specific aspect or characteristic of something. In this context, it implies extracting relevant information from the subject (ontological frameworks) and describing or representing that information in terms of its relationship with the object (bio-signal markers and technological interfaces for the entire human body). The predicate 'capture' suggests a mapping or correlation between the subject's conceptual framework and the object's physical or biological properties, allowing for a deeper understanding of their interplay.

Predicate-be_one_of_the_main_development.label: be one of the main development drivers in the future for
Predicate-be_one_of_the_main_development.description: The predicate 'be one of the main development drivers in the future for' indicates a directional relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (e.g., modeling task) will play a significant role in shaping or influencing the object's (e.g., ontological frameworks) evolution, growth, or direction over time.

Predicate-proposing_extensions_to.label: proposing extensions to
Predicate-proposing_extensions_to.description: The predicate 'proposing extensions to' indicates a proposal or suggestion for modifications or additions to something (the object), typically with the intention of improving, expanding, or refining its existing characteristics. The subject is responsible for making this proposal and connecting it to the specific entity being extended.

Predicate-following.label: following
Predicate-following.description: The predicate 'following' indicates a state of tracking or pursuing something, often in a sequential manner. It implies that the subject is actively monitoring, keeping up with, or adhering to the object, which can be an idea, concept, process, or sequence.

Predicate-providing_feedback_from.label: providing feedback from
Predicate-providing_feedback_from.description: The predicate 'providing feedback from' indicates a source or origin of evaluative comments, insights, or assessments that inform or shape the subject's understanding or perspective. It suggests a connection between the subject and the object, where the former draws upon or derives value from the latter in order to form its own viewpoint.

Predicate-regarding.label: regarding
Predicate-regarding.description: The predicate 'regarding' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject is being discussed or considered in relation to the topic described by the object. It suggests that the subject has some connection, relevance, or pertinence to the matter addressed by the object.

Predicate-tracking.label: tracking
Predicate-tracking.description: The predicate 'tracking' indicates a process of monitoring or keeping pace with something (the object), often to understand its development, evolution, or changes. It implies a sense of attention and focus on the subject's part, as they strive to comprehend or keep up with the object.

Predicate-providing_feedback_from_the_BC.label: providing feedback from the BCI-O perspective in their ongoing discussions
Predicate-providing_feedback_from_the_BC.description: The predicate 'providing feedback from the BCI-O perspective in their ongoing discussions' describes the act of offering insights, comments or suggestions by the subject (BCI-O) regarding a specific topic or issue (object), while considering its own unique viewpoint and context. This action involves engaging with others through continuous dialogue, sharing knowledge and ideas to facilitate understanding, improvement, or decision-making.

Predicate-keep.label: keep
Predicate-keep.description: To maintain or preserve something as a part of its inherent nature or identity. This predicate indicates that the subject has a connection to the object such that it retains or continues to possess certain characteristics, properties, or aspects.

Predicate-store.label: store
Predicate-store.description: To store means to retain or keep something (e.g. data, information, etc.) in a designated location for future reference or use.

Predicate-plan_to_work_on.label: plan to work on
Predicate-plan_to_work_on.description: To indicate a intention or commitment by the subject (As an aside project) to dedicate effort and resources towards developing, refining, or improving the object (OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O), which represents a specific task, concept, or idea.

Predicate-so_that_those_relevant_metadat.label: so that those relevant metadata sets can be queried through a restrictive version of
Predicate-so_that_those_relevant_metadat.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) provides a means or mechanism for querying relevant metadata sets through a restricted version of another entity (the object).

Predicate-aid.label: aid
Predicate-aid.description: The predicate 'aid' indicates a relationship where the subject provides support or assistance to achieve a goal or solve a problem. The object represents the means, methods, or tools used to accomplish this aid.

Predicate-associates.label: associates
Predicate-associates.description: The predicate 'associates' establishes a connection between two entities by linking them through a shared concept or relationship. It implies that one entity (the subject) has a meaningful link to another entity (the object), which can be characterized as an attribute, characteristic, or aspect of the subject.

Predicate-assisting.label: assisting
Predicate-assisting.description: The predicate 'assisting' indicates a relationship where one entity (the subject) provides support or facilitation to another entity (the object), enabling it to function, operate, or achieve its intended purpose more effectively.

Predicate-serve_as.label: serve as
Predicate-serve_as.description: The predicate 'serve as' indicates a functional relationship between its subject and object. It suggests that the subject provides or fulfills some role, function, or purpose for the object. In general, it implies that the subject acts as a substitute, representation, or embodiment of the object's intended meaning, functionality, or significance.

Predicate-enable_BCI_systems_to_apply_Se.label: enable BCI systems to apply Semantic Web technologies for data analysis
Predicate-enable_BCI_systems_to_apply_Se.description: This predicate enables Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems to utilize the capabilities of Semantic Web technologies for analyzing and processing data. It facilitates the integration of BCI systems with the semantic web, allowing them to leverage its features such as ontology-based reasoning, query languages, and data interoperability.

Predicate-assists.label: assists
Predicate-assists.description: The predicate 'assists' indicates a supportive or facilitating relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject provides help, guidance, or resources to enable the object's functioning, development, or achievement.

Predicate-generalizes.label: generalizes
Predicate-generalizes.description: To generalize means to establish a broader or more abstract connection between two concepts, ideas, or systems. The predicate 'generalizes' indicates that the subject (a work, concept, theory, etc.) establishes a higher-level relationship with the object (another concept, system, framework, etc.), often by identifying patterns, principles, or commonalities.

Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.label: formalizes relevant metadata for
Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.description: Transforms a subject entity by assigning or organizing relevant metadata that describes its characteristics, properties, or relationships with other entities, thereby providing a structured and standardized representation of the subject for further analysis, processing, or integration.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: The predicate 'supports' indicates a relationship where the subject provides resources, infrastructure, or mechanisms that enable or facilitate the object's existence, operation, or functionality. In general, it suggests a connection between the subject and object where the former enables or sustains the latter.

Predicate-was_developed.label: was developed
Predicate-was_developed.description: Indicates that a concept or artifact was created through a process of design, implementation, testing, and refinement. This predicate connects the subject (the thing being described) to the object (the description of how it came into existence), highlighting the intentional and deliberate nature of its development.

Predicate-can_greatly_enhance.label: can greatly enhance
Predicate-can_greatly_enhance.description: The predicate 'can greatly enhance' indicates a potential improvement or augmentation of the object by the subject. It suggests that the subject has the capability to significantly improve, amplify, or expand the capabilities or effectiveness of the object.

Predicate-present_based_on.label: present based on
Predicate-present_based_on.description: The predicate 'present based on' indicates a relationship between the subject (the entity presenting something) and the object (the basis or foundation upon which the presentation is made. This connection suggests that the subject's presentation is grounded in, informed by, or derived from the specified object, such as design patterns, ontologies, or other conceptual frameworks.

Predicate-was_developed_as_part_of.label: was developed as part of
Predicate-was_developed_as_part_of.description: Indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or concept) has its development or creation closely tied to or influenced by another entity, project, model, or framework represented as the object. This predicate suggests that the subject's development was guided, informed, or built upon the principles, methods, or resources provided by the object.

Predicate-formalize.label: formalize
Predicate-formalize.description: To formalize means to transform or reorganize something (typically an idea, concept, or process) from a less structured or informal state into a more organized and systematic one. This predicate connects the subject with the object by indicating that the subject has undergone a transformation to become more formalized in relation to the object.

Predicate-generalizes_towards.label: generalizes towards
Predicate-generalizes_towards.description: The predicate 'generalizes towards' indicates that the subject (a concept or framework) provides a broader and more abstract representation of the object, which can be a specific domain, theory, or ontology. The relationship suggests that the subject's generalization encompasses or is related to the object in some way.

Predicate-integrates_Sense_and_Actuation.label: integrates Sense and Actuation Models along with
Predicate-integrates_Sense_and_Actuation.description: The predicate 'integrates Sense and Actuation Models along with' indicates a unifying or combining relationship between two entities (subject and object), where the subject integrates its internal models of sensing and actuating, as well as other external components or systems represented by the object. This integration enables the creation of a comprehensive framework that can effectively interact with or respond to various stimuli.

Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.label: formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating
Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.description: The predicate 'formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating' connects the subject and object by describing a process of organizing and structuring relevant information related to brain-computer interface (BCI) data capture, which involves combining or linking different components or elements. This integration enables the creation of standardized and meaningful representations of BCI data, facilitating its analysis, interpretation, and utilization.

Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.label: formalizes relevant metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction data capture activities by integrating Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model
Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.description: This predicate connects the subject to an object that represents a process of organizing relevant metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction data capture activities by integrating Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model. The connection highlights the role of this integration in formalizing metadata, emphasizing its importance in structuring BCI-related information.

Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.label: formalizes relevant metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction data capture activities
Predicate-formalizes_relevant_metadata_f.description: This predicate connects a subject (e.g., a brain-computer interface system or dataset) to an object (e.g., a metadata structure), indicating that relevant metadata has been standardized and organized for Brain-Computer Interaction data capture activities. The predicate formalizes the relationship between the subject's characteristics, properties, and context with the structured information required for effective data management, analysis, and sharing.

Predicate-is_formalized_in.label: is formalized in
Predicate-is_formalized_in.description: The predicate 'is formalized in' indicates a relationship between an entity (subject) and its representation or framework that provides a structured organization of concepts, rules, or principles. The object represents a specific structure, syntax, or notation used to formally express the subject's content, making it more precise, standardized, and easily accessible.

Predicate-develops_into.label: develops into
Predicate-develops_into.description: The predicate 'develops into' indicates a transformation or evolution of the subject towards the object. It suggests that the subject undergoes a process of change, growth, or maturation to become more like or converge with the described state or entity represented by the object.

Predicate-develops.label: develops
Predicate-develops.description: The predicate 'develops' indicates a process of growth, maturation or refinement that transforms the subject into something new or improved. It implies an intentional effort to advance or progress towards a specific goal or outcome.

Predicate-develop.label: develop
Predicate-develop.description: To develop means to bring something into being or to cause it to grow and mature. It implies a process of transformation, refinement, or improvement from an initial state to a more advanced one. In this sense, the predicate 'develop' connects the subject (the entity undergoing development) with the object (the outcome or result of that development), indicating a causal relationship where the subject's potential is realized through the action of developing.

Predicate-generalize_into.label: generalize into
Predicate-generalize_into.description: The predicate 'generalize into' indicates that the subject's generalization or abstraction process results in a mapping or transformation of concepts from one domain (represented by the object) to another, often creating a common framework for understanding and communication between different fields or disciplines.

Predicate-generalize.label: generalize
Predicate-generalize.description: To generalize means to establish or infer a broader principle, pattern, or relationship from specific instances or data. It involves identifying commonalities and abstracting away from individual details to create a more comprehensive understanding.

Predicate-integrate.label: integrate
Predicate-integrate.description: To combine or unify two entities (subject and object) into a cohesive whole, often resulting in a new entity that represents their relationship. This integration can involve merging distinct components, reconciling conflicting information, or creating a unified framework from disparate parts.

Predicate-is_generalization_towards.label: is generalization towards
Predicate-is_generalization_towards.description: The predicate 'is generalization towards' indicates that the subject represents an abstraction or summary of information, which serves as a direction or orientation point for understanding the object. In other words, it suggests that the subject provides a higher-level perspective or framework for interpreting the meaning and significance of the object.

Predicate-is_formalized_by.label: <is formalized by>
Predicate-is_formalized_by.description: The predicate '<is formalized by>' indicates a relationship between an abstract concept (the subject) and its underlying representation or structure, which provides a systematic organization of the concept's components. This connection highlights how the subject has been given a concrete form that facilitates understanding, analysis, or manipulation.

Predicate-allows.label: allows
Predicate-allows.description: The predicate 'allows' indicates that the subject has permission or enables the object to occur, exist, or be performed. It implies a facilitation of some kind, where the subject provides an opportunity for the object to happen or take place.

Predicate-integrates_BCI-domain-specific.label: integrates BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with
Predicate-integrates_BCI-domain-specific.description: The predicate 'integrates BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with' connects a subject (a model or framework in a specific domain) to an object (typically, a brain-computer interface-oriented system), indicating that the former incorporates or unifies the latter's sense-making and action-taking capabilities within its own scope.

Predicate-are_used_in.label: are used in
Predicate-are_used_in.description: The predicate 'are used in' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., Brain-Computer Interfaces) employs or utilizes something described by the object (e.g., BCI metadata annotations). This connection suggests that the subject relies on, incorporates, or makes use of the information provided by the object to function, operate, or achieve its purpose.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or example of a more general concept represented by the object. The relationship between the subject and object is one of instantiation, where the subject is a concrete realization of the abstract idea or category denoted by the object.
